head.title: For the Adventurous, an Earthbound Ride on the Shuttle

hedline.hl1: For the Adventurous, an Earthbound Ride on the Shuttle

block.p: Hitching a ride on the space shuttle comes to the lucky few only after a long selection process and arduous training. But the Kennedy Space Center visitor complex has worked with current and former astronauts to develop a ride that just may be the next best thing.

Hitching a ride on the space shuttle comes to the lucky few only after a long selection process and arduous training. But the Kennedy Space Center visitor complex has worked with current and former astronauts to develop a ride that just may be the next best thing.

The $60 million Shuttle Launch Experience opened Memorial Day weekend. The 44,000-square-foot building holds four simulators, each of which can accommodate 44 people, taking them through a special effects-heavy approximation of the stages of launching and ascent.

The production opens with visitors standing for a ''pre-launch briefing'' on video by Brig. Gen. Charles F. Bolden Jr., now retired, who was twice a shuttle commander in his four flights. General Bolden's lively description of the basics is punctuated by powerful bass speakers providing a sensory jolt. Then visitors strap into their seats in the simulator, which looks like an overgrown can that has been loaded into the payload bay of a shuttle.

At ''liftoff'' there are more sounds and shaking seats. The entire simulator rears back on hydraulic lifts, setting the passengers up at a nearly 70-degree angle. As the sound and shaking intensifies, air bladders concealed in the seat cushions soften to give the feeling of being pressed back into the seats by the three-G force of ascent.
There is a slight power decrease during ''Max Q,'' the period of maximum stress on the vehicle during ascent, when the shuttle briefly eases off its power and then ramps it up again.

There is a noise and jolt as the solid rocket boosters are blown away from the shuttle, and another when the external tank is released -- and the simulator rocks back toward the floor and points slightly downward to emulate the thrown-into-the-straps feeling that astronauts describe as they first encounter the reduced acceleration and gravity of orbit.

On a real flight, that part of the ascent would have taken eight and a half minutes, but for the passengers on the ride, barely five minutes pass. At that point, the payload bay opens, celestial music plays, and the passengers see a projected image of Earth sliding by below.

Col. Richard A. Searfoss, a former shuttle commander, used what he called an ''astronaut-calibrated rear end'' to help the companies that designed and developed the ride. ''I am just amazed how good they've gotten it,'' Colonel Searfoss said.

On Wednesday, Matthew Eyers, a 12-year-old visiting Florida with his family from Hampshire, England, said he enjoyed the ride -- even if, by some standards, the shuttle is yesterday's news. A few days before, he had ridden the retro-futuristic Space Mountain ride at Tomorrowland in the Magic Kingdom at Walt Disney World.
''This is realistic,'' Matthew said with satisfaction. His father, Tim Eyers, put it differently: ''This is more down to earth.''
